Dry reforming of methane (DRM) holds great economic value and environmental protection significance. In our previous study, an in-situ reduced Ni-doped BaZrO3-δ-based catalyst was used as the DRM reforming layer, which exhibited remarkable coking-resistance. To further enhance its DRM catalytic activity and durability, Ce was doped at the B-site of Ba0.9Zr0.7Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ, and the positive effects of Ce doping on DRM catalytic activity was investigated. Among the various Ce-doped catalysts, the perovskite catalyst with a Ce doping amount of 20 mol. % (i.e., Ba0.9Zr0.5Ce0.2Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ) demonstrated the highest catalytic activity. At 750 °C, the CH4 and CO2 conversions reached as high as 80.1 % and 85.3 % respectively. Additionally, this catalyst exhibited excellent DRM catalytic durability, and no coking was detected after a 60 h durability test at 700 °C. The enhanced DRM catalytic activity and high coking-resistance can be attributed to the increased concentration of oxygen vacancies, improved hydration capacity, and enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity. The Ce doping in perovskite catalysts provides valuable insights for the construction of DRM catalysts with superior catalytic activity and durability. Introduction Energy shortage and the greenhouse effect are two main major issues that hinder the development of the global economy. The combustion of fossil fuels leads to the release of a significant amount of carbon dioxide (CO2), which is the primary cause of the greenhouse effect [1–3]. Consequently, various strategies have been proposed to capture and utilize CO2. Methane (CH4), another greenhouse gas, is abundantly available in nature as the primary component of natural gas [4,5]. Dry reforming of methane (DRM: CO2+CH4=2H2+2CO, ΔH 298=+247 kJ mol−1) is an crucial method for converting both CH4 and CO2 into syngas (H2 and CO) with a H2/CO ratio of 1.0 [6–11]. The produced syngas can be utilized as fuel or further synthesized into other chemicals through the Fischer-Tropsch (F-T) process [12]. DRM catalysts typically utilize supported Group VIII metals such as Ru, Rh, Pd, Pt, Ni, Co, etc. [13–16]. Among these supported catalysts, Ni-based catalysts have gained significant attention due to their high catalytic activity and cost-effectiveness. However, the operation of DRM requires high temperatures due to its strong endothermic nature [17]. At elevated temperatures, Ni-based catalysts are prone to metal sintering and coking resulting from CH4 decomposition and CO disproportionation, leading to rapid catalyst deactivation [9,18]. To address this issue, various catalyst structure design methods have been proposed to enhance the catalytic durability of Ni-based catalysts. These methods include the introduction of lattice oxygen [19,20], the preparation of bimetallic catalysts [21–23], the reduction of Ni nanoparticle size [24], the enhancement of interface force, and surface modification of Ni nanoparticles [25–27]. Perovskite-based catalysts with an ABO3 crystal structure exhibit excellent high-temperature stability, which enhances the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles and their interface force with the substrate after reduction in H2 [28–30]. Moreover, substituting A-site elements in the perovskite lattice can increase the concentration of oxygen vacancies, thereby promoting carbon oxidation [24,31,32]. For instance, the Ni particle size in the La0.46Sr0.34Ti0.9Ni0.1O3-δ catalyst prepared by the combustion method was smaller compared to impregnation, and it also exhibited improved coking-resistance [24]. Increasing the Sr concentration in the La0.8- x Sr x Cr0.85Ni0.15O3-δ perovskite catalyst enhanced the alkalinity and oxygen vacancy concentration of the substrate, resulting in higher catalytic durability [33]. Therefore, by strategically designing the structure of Ni-based perovskite catalysts, it is possible to effectively suppress coking and metal sintering, thereby improving catalytic durability. Our previous studies confirmed that in-situ reduced Ni-doped BaZrO3-δ-based perovskite oxide exhibited high catalytic activity and durability for DRM [34]. The in-situ exsolved Ni nanoparticles are uniformly embedded on the BaZr0.8Y0.2O3-δ substrate, which plays a crucial role in the coking-resistance of the catalyst. It has been well-established that Ce doping at the B-site of perovskite oxides can effectively increase the oxygen vacancy concentration [35,36], which is essential for the catalytic activity and durability of the catalysts. To further improve the DRM catalytic activity and durability of the Ni-doped BaZrO3-δ catalyst, Ce was doped at the B-site of Ba0.9Zr0.7Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ in this study. The DRM catalytic activity, catalytic durability, and coking-resistance of Ba0.9Zr0.7- x Ce x Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ (x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.6) catalysts were investigated in detail. The introduction of A-site defects can further enhance the oxygen vacancy concentration of the perovskite oxide. Ce doping is beneficial for improving the hydration and CO2 adsorption capacities of the catalyst, which are of great significance for enhancing catalytic activity and coking-resistance. Ce doping in perovskite catalysts provides valuable insights for the construction of DRM catalysts with high catalytic activity and durability. Material and methods Materials synthesis Ba0.9Zr0.7- x Ce x Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ (Cex, x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.6) catalysts were synthesized using a commonly used self-combustion method. In brief, metal nitrate solution was prepared by dissolving Ba(NO3)2, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Y(NO3)3·6H2O, and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in deionized water according to the stoichiometric ratio. Ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) was heated and dissolved in ammonia solution, and slowly added to the prepared metal nitrate solution. Subsequently, citric acid monohydrate (CA) was added to the mixed solution, and the pH value of the mixed solution was adjusted to ∼8 by ammonia solution. In the above process, the molar ratio of the total amount of metal ions, EDTA and CA was 1:1:2. The mixed solution was continuously heated and stirred until it evaporated to ∼50 mL. The concentrate was then transferred to a ceramic bowl for self-combustion during heating up to 300 °C. Ashes were collected and then heat-treated at 1000 °C for 2 h in air to obtain Cex powders. Catalyst performance characterizations The catalytic activity and durability of Cex catalysts for DRM were investigated using a fixed quartz tube, which was placed inside a programmable heating vertical muffle furnace. A mixed powder containing 0.1 g Cex catalyst and 0.3 g quartz sand was evenly spread on quartz wool and positioned in the middle of the reactor. Prior to conducting the DRM reaction, the Cex catalysts underwent a reduction process. H2 was continuously supplied to the reactor at a flow rate of 15 mL min−1 to reduce the catalyst powder, and this reduction process lasted for 2 h at 750 °C. During the DRM reaction, H2 was switched to CH4 CO2 (50 vol. %CH4 and 50 vol. %CO2, 15 mL min−1), and the exhaust gas was analysed by gas chromatograph (GC-9560-HA, Shanghai Huaai Chromatographic Analysis Technology Co., Ltd.). DRM catalytic durability tests were performed at 700 °C. At this temperature, CH4 CO2 was continuously supplied to the reactor, and the composition of the exhaust gas was analysed by GC every 1 h. Other characterizations The phase and crystal structure of the prepared Cex powder before and after reduction were determined using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. The XRD measurements were conducted using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE instrument with Cu Kα radiation at 40 KV and 30 mA. To assess the chemical stability of the Cex catalysts in a CH4 CO2 environment, the Cex powders were subjected to a flowing CH4 CO2 atmosphere for heat-treatment at 750 °C for 4 h, followed by XRD characterizations. The valence electronic structures of the prepared Ce0.2 and reduced Ce0.2 were analysed using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, ESCALAB XI+), and the core levels of Ce 3d and Ni 3p were recorded. The element distribution and crystallographic information of the reduced Ce0.2 powder were obtained using a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Thermo Fisher Scientific, TalosF200X G2). To detect the presence of coking on the Ce0 and Ce0.2 catalyst after the DRM durability test, the post-tested powders were subjected to thermogravimetry (TGA, Mettler Toledo TGA2) analysis. The TGA measurements were carried out in air, with the temperature ranging from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The micromorphologies of the post-tested Ce0 and Ce0.2 catalysts were observed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, FEI, Apreo S HiVac). Coking in the post-tested Ce0 and Ce0.2 catalysts were detected by Raman spectroscopy (Thermo Fisher Scientific, RXD2). To evaluate the CO2 adsorption capacities of the Ce0 and Ce0.2 catalysts, CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) tests were conducted. 0.2 g catalyst powder was pre-treated at 300 °C in a U-shaped quartz tube for 1 h under an Ar flow, and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, the treated sample was heated to 750 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 and held for 1 h in a 10 % CO2–90 % Ar flow (30 mL min−1). After the sample was cooled to room temperature in CO2-Ar atmosphere, it was purged with an Ar flow (30 mL min−1), and the signal of CO2 in the exhaust gas was detected by a mass spectrometer (MS, Pfeiffer Hicube RGA, Pfeiffer Vacuum). After the CO2 signal stabilized, the sample was heated from room temperature to 950 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, and the CO2 signal in the exhaust gas was recorded by MS during this process. Results and discussion BaCeO3- and BaZrO3-based perovskite oxides are commonly used as electrolyte materials in proton ceramic fuel cells due to their high proton transport capacity [37–39]. However, the former suffers from low chemical stability, while the latter has low sintering ability and high grain boundary resistance [40–42]. To address these issues, a solid solution product of BaZrO3 and BaCeO3, namely BaCe1- x Zr x O3 perovskite, can provide a trade-off between chemical stability, sintering-ability, and conductivity by adjusting the ratio [43]. In this study, Ce was doped at the B-site of Ba0.9Zr0.7Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ catalyst to investigate the effect of Ce doping on its catalytic activity and stability. Ce doping at the B-site of BaZrO3-based perovskite can effectively increase the oxygen vacancy concentration, which is closely related to the catalytic activity of BaZrO3-based catalysts. By doping Ce in the catalyst, it is expected to enhance the catalytic activity and durability of the Ba0.9Zr0.7Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ catalyst for the desired application. The XRD patterns of the prepared Cex catalysts (Fig. 1 a) indicate the successful doping of Ce in the BaZrO3-based perovskite, as all the samples exhibit the standard perovskite phase without impurities. It was observed that the diffraction peaks shift to the left as a whole with increasing Ce doping amount. This shift is attributed to the larger ionic radius of Ce ions compared to Zr ions, leading to lattice expansion. Rietveld refinement analysis of the XRD patterns further confirms the lattice expansion caused by Ce doping. As shown in Fig. 1, all Cex catalysts exhibited the Pm3m space group, and their crystal unit-cell parameters gradually increased from 4.204 to 4.365 Å with increasing Ce doping amount. After H2-treatment at 750 °C for 4 h, the phase composition of the catalysts changed, as shown in Fig. 1b. Besides the perovskite phase, a small amount of metallic Ni phase was detected. The micromorphology of the reduced Ce0.2 catalyst was observed, as shown in Fig. 2 . Before reduction, the various elements of the catalyst were evenly distributed. However, Ni element aggregate on the surface of the grain, forming nanoparticles, while other elements maintain a uniform distribution, as shown in Fig. 2a. High-resolution TEM image of the Ni-enriched regions on the grain surface reveals that the nanoparticle are embedded onto the substrate. The substrate has an interplanar spacing of 0.2926 nm, as shown in Fig. 2c, which is close to the (110) crystal plane of BaZrO3 (0.2957 nm, PDF#74–1299). Rietveld refinement analysis on the XRD pattern of Ce0.2 (Fig. 1d) confirms the interplanar spacing of the substrate. The unit-cell parameter a of the substrate oxide is identified to be 0.4248 nm, resulting in an interplanar spacing of 0.3004 nm for the (110) crystal plane. This calculated value is very close to the measured value in the TEM image (Fig. 2c), further verifying that the substrate is BaZrO3-based perovskite oxide. The nanoparticle within the Ni-enriched regions has an interplanar spacing of 0.2013 nm (shown in Fig. 2d), which is close to the interplanar spacing of the (111) crystal plane of metallic Ni (0.2034 nm, PDF#04–0850). This suggests that Ni in-situ exsolves from the lattice of the perovskite oxide, forming Ni metal nanoparticles in a reducing environment. Additionally, these Ni nanoparticles are embedded on the surface of the perovskite substrate. An A-site-deficient structure was designed in this study, and the aim was to achieve complete exsolution of Ni nanoparticles after reduction. To verify this conclusion, XPS was performed on reduced Ce0 and Ce0.2 powders. Fig. 3 shows the Ni 2p3/2 XPS spectra of the reduced Ce0 and Ce0.2 powders. The Ni 2p3/2 XPS spectra are fitted into three peaks: Ni0 peak at 853 eV [44], and sat. peaks at 861.1 and 856.9 eV [45,46]. No characteristic peaks of Ni in other valences were detected. This XPS result clearly suggested the formation of Ni nanoparticles after reduction, and all Ni elements in Ce0 and Ce0.2 lattices were in-situ exsolved on the surface of the substrate. This conclusion is consistent with a previous study by Shao et al. [47]. In their research, they reported the formation of 0.2 mol Ni nanoparticles after the complete reduction of 1 mol Ba(Zr0.4Ce0.4Y0.2)0.8Ni0.2O3-δ perovskite oxide in H2. The lower Ni content and the presence of A-site defects in the Ce0.2 catalyst make it more favourable for the complete exsolution of Ni nanoparticles. The DRM catalytic activity of Cex catalysts was evaluated by measuring the CH4 and CO2 conversions. Fig. 4 shows the DRM catalytic activity of Cex catalysts at different temperatures. As the temperature increased, the catalytic activities of the catalysts improved significantly, which could be attributed to the high temperature favouring the DRM reaction. Ce0 exhibited mediocre DRM catalytic activity, with CH4 and CO2 conversions of only 61.1 % and 72.1 % at 750 °C, respectively. In contrast, Ce0.2 showed significantly improved DRM catalytic activity, with CH4 and CO2 conversions increasing to 80.1 % and 85.3 % at 750 °C, respectively. This in-situ exsolved catalyst demonstrated better DRM catalytic activity compared to some other Ni-based catalysts, as shown in Table 1 . As confirmed in XPS result of prepared Ce0.2 powder (Fig. 5 a and 5b), the valence of Ce in Ba0.9Zr0.7- x Ce x Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ is mixed +3/+4, which is lower than +4 valence of Zr. The partial substitution of Zr by Ce inevitably leads to a reduction in the total valence state of cations, resulting in an increase in oxygen vacancies to maintain electrical neutrality. The increase in oxygen vacancy concentration has been reported in other studies as well [35,36]. According to the proton transport mechanism of proton ceramic electrolyte, the high oxygen vacancy concentration resulting from Ce doping enhances the hydration capacity of BaZrO3-δ-based perovskite oxides [48–50]. Additionally, the increased oxygen vacancy concentration also improves the CO2 adsorption capacity of the substrate [51–53]. According to the reforming mechanism of Ni-based catalysts [54–57], CH4 cracking occurs at the active sites on the Ni surface, while the adsorption of cracking of CO2/H2O occurs at the active sites of the substate. The O2− generated by the CO2/H2O cracking is transported to the active sites of Ni through the oxygen vacancies of the substrate, where it reacts with carbon species produced by CH4 cracking. In summary, Ce doping enhances the CO2/H2O adsorption capacity and oxygen vacancy concentration of the substrate, leading to an accelerated generation of O2− at the active sites of the substrate and an increased bulk transport rate. These factors contribute to the improved DRM catalytic activity of the Ce0.2 catalyst. The reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ after reduction is a common phenomenon in Ce-based oxides. However, in the case of Ce0.2 catalyst, the ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ hardly changed before and after reduction, as shown in Fig. 5a and 5b. This strange phenomenon can be attributed to the Ni exsolution. In a reducing atmosphere, Ni2+ is reduced to Ni0, causing a drop in the B-site valence. To prevent further reduction of the B-site valence and maintain the stability of the perovskite structure, Ce4+ is hardly reduced. In addition to the DRM reaction, CH4-CO2 undergoes a series of side reactions under the catalysis of the Ni-based catalyst, as shown in Fig. 5c. The gas environment around the catalyst is complex, including CH4, CO2, CO, H2, steam, etc. The enhanced hydration capacity of the Ce0.2 catalyst is beneficial for the steam reforming reaction of CH4 (CH4+H2O→CO+3H2). Additionally, Ce doping improves the CO2 adsorption property of BaZrO3-δ-based perovskite oxides, as shown in Fig. 5d. The Ce0.2 catalyst exhibited significantly higher CO2 desorption compared to the Ce0 catalyst, indicating an enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity. This can be attributed to the increased oxygen vacancy concentration in Ce0.2. During the DRM reaction, CO2 molecules are adsorbed and dissociated on the surface of the substrate, forming CO and O species. The former forms CO molecules, while the O species are accepted by the oxygen vacancies of the substrate. Therefore, a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies in the substrate promotes the DRM process [29,33,62]. Therefore, significantly improved catalytic activity was exhibited after Ce doping. However, Ce0.4 and Ce0.6 exhibited quite low CH4 and CO2 conversions at 750 °C (Fig. 4), indicating their negligible DRM catalytic activity. This can be attributed to their weak chemical stability in the CH4-CO2 atmosphere, as shown in Fig. 6 . Ce0 and Ce0.2 catalysts demonstrated excellent stability in the CH4-CO2 environment, with no impurities detected after the heat-treatment. In contrast, Ce0.4 and Ce0.6 underwent noticeable phase decomposition and the formation of carbon after the heat-treatment at 750 °C in CH4-CO2 for 4 h, thus leading to their low DRM catalytic activities. Catalytic durability is an important factor in assessing the performance of catalysts. In the case of the in-situ exsolved Ni-based catalysts, the uniformly distribution of Ni nanoparticles on the perovskite substrate prevents their agglomeration. Coking, which is caused by CH4 cracking and CO disproportionation, is an crucial factor affecting the durability of Ni-based catalysts in DRM reactions [33]. Among the Cex catalysts, Ce0.2 exhibited the highest DRM catalytic activity, and its catalytic durability was further investigated, as shown in Fig. 7 a. The CH4 conversion of Ce0.2 remained at approximately 71 % throughout the durability test at 700 °C, indicating excellent catalytic durability of Ce0.2 catalyst. In contrast, Ce0 catalyst exhibited poor catalytic stability, with a decrease in CH4 conversion from 46.3 to 41.2 % within 60 h. This decrease in DRM catalytic activity is likely due to coking. To confirm this, Ce0 and Ce0.2 powder after the durability test were subjected to TG analysis in air, as shown in Fig. 7b. The post-tested Ce0.2 catalyst exhibited only ∼0.5 % mass loss when heated from room temperature to 800 °C. The TG curve can be roughly divided into three sections: the mass loss stage from room temperature to 400 °C, the mass increase stage from 400 to 600 °C, and the mass loss stage after 600 °C, corresponding to the desorption of surface adsorbates, the oxidation of Ce0.2, and the increase of oxygen vacancies in Ce0.2, respectively. In contrast, the post-tested Ce0 catalyst showed a mass loss of 2.2 %, which was significantly lagger than that of the post-tested Ce0.2 catalyst. Its TG curve can be divided into two stages, with the former attributed to the desorption of adsorbates and the latter indicating the oxidation of coking. The presence of coking in the post-tested Ce0 powder was confirmed in SEM image, as shown in Fig. 7c. However, no coking was detected in the micromorphology of the post-tested Ce0.2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 7c, indicating excellent resistance to coking. Raman spectrum analysis shown in Fig. 7d further confirmed the presence of coking in the post-tested Ce0 catalyst, as evidence from the carbon vibration peaks observed at 1360 cm−1 and 1585 cm−1. In contrast, no coking was detected in post-tested Ce0.2 powder. In Ni-based DRM catalysts, the adsorption of CH4 and the cleavage of C–H bonds occur on the surface of Ni particles during the reaction. As carbon is formed by CH4 cracking, it dissolves into the Ni particles. When the concentration of carbon reaches its upper solubility limit in Ni, carbon-fibers start to form and accumulate at the Ni/substrate interface. These carbon-fibers grow and lift the Ni particles from the substrate, leaving them at the tip of the carbon-fibers [63–65]. Therefore, the Ni/substrate interaction is crucial for the formation of carbon-fibers. If the interfacial interaction is strong enough, the formation of carbon-fibers can be suppressed; conversely, carbon-fibers are more likely to form on the surface of Ni particles. After reduction, in-situ exsolved Ni nanoparticles are embedded onto the surface of the perovskite substrate, as confirmed in Fig. 2. This strong Ni/substrate interfacial interaction contributes to the excellent coking-resistance of the catalysts. Additionally, the high concentration of oxygen vacancies in the substrate helps to eliminate deposited carbon. Sufficient oxygen can transport to the active sites of Ni particles through these oxygen vacancies, facilitating the timely oxidizing of carbon species. As mentioned earlier, Ce doping increases the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the BaZrO3-δ-based substrate oxide, thereby improving the coking resistance of the Ce0.2 catalyst. In contrast, the oxygen vacancy concentration in the substrate of the Ce0 catalyst is low. As a result, O2− dissociated from CO2 cannot reach the active sites of Ni particles in a timely manner, leading to coking. Conclusions Ba0.9Zr0.7- x Ce x Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ (Cex, x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.6) catalysts were successful synthesized by a self-combustion method. After reduction in H2, all the Ni element in-situ exsolved from the lattice of the perovskite oxide, and formed Ni nanoparticles that were embedded onto the surface of the perovskite substrate. The catalytic activity of the Cex catalysts in the DRM reaction increased with increasing Ce doping amount. This enhancement can be attributed to the increased oxygen vacancies, enhanced hydration capacity, and CO2 adsorption capacity of the catalysts. Nevertheless, Ce0.4 and Ce0.6 catalysts exhibited low chemical stability in the CH4-CO2 environment, resulting in negligible DRM catalytic activity. Among the Cex catalysts, Ce0.2 showed the highest catalytic activity, with CH4 and CO2 conversions reaching as high as 80.1 % and 85.3 % at 750 °C, respectively. In addition to its high DRM catalytic activity, Ce0.2 catalyst also demonstrated outstanding catalytic durability, with no coking detected in the post-tested catalyst. This excellent catalytic durability can be attributed to the strong Ni/substrate interfacial interaction and high oxygen vacancy concentration. The findings of this study provide valuable guidance for the construction of DRM catalysts with both high catalytic activity and durability. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) holds great economic value and environmental protection significance. In our previous study, an in-situ reduced Ni-doped BaZrO3-δ-based catalyst was used as the DRM reforming layer, which exhibited remarkable coking-resistance. To further enhance its DRM catalytic activity and durability, Ce was doped at the B-site of Ba0.9Zr0.7Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ, and the positive effects of Ce doping on DRM catalytic activity was investigated. Among the various Ce-doped catalysts, the perovskite catalyst with a Ce doping amount of 20 mol. % (i.e., Ba0.9Zr0.5Ce0.2Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ) demonstrated the highest catalytic activity. At 750 °C, the CH4 and CO2 conversions reached as high as 80.1 % and 85.3 % respectively. Additionally, this catalyst exhibited excellent DRM catalytic durability, and no coking was detected after a 60 h durability test at 700 °C. The enhanced DRM catalytic activity and high coking-resistance can be attributed to the increased concentration of oxygen vacancies, improved hydration capacity, and enhanced CO2 adsorption capacity. The Ce doping in perovskite catalysts provides valuable insights for the construction of DRM catalysts with superior catalytic activity and durability.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic activity for methane dry reforming of Ce-doped Ba0.9Zr0.7Y0.2Ni0.1O3-δ perovskite catalyst
